item.title: Panetta to Visit Asia to Discuss Military’s Shift There
item.description: Defense Secretary Leon Panetta will outline how the Pentagon is refocusing on the Pacific, as the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are over or winding down.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: News Analysis: European Union Celebrates German and Dutch Decisions
item.description: A decision by the German Constitutional Court and results from a Dutch election may mean that the worst is over for the euro, or so European Union leaders hope.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: The Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, left, after his Liberal Party won the most seats in Parliament. Voters rejected anti-European Union parties.

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Absence Puts Communist Party Off Script
item.description: If and when China’s presumptive new leader, Xi Jinping, re-emerges, he will do so in the midst of a contentious Communist Party preparing to shake up its leadership.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:credit: Pool photo by How Hwee Young
item.media:description: Xi Jinping on Aug. 29. Some analysts believe he has had a heart attack or stroke.

item.title: Chinese Ships Enter Waters Japan Controls
item.description: It was the first such move by China since Japan announced that it had bought a group of disputed islands in the East China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Romney Aides Detail Foreign Policy Differences
item.description: Tying Egypt’s debt forgiveness to the country’s efforts to protect American interests there and shaping a post-Qaddafi Libya were among the specific positions Mitt Romney’s advisers said he would take.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ASHLEY PARKER
item.media:description: Mitt Romney campaigned in Fairfax, Va., on Thursday.

item.title: Khanbogd Journal: Oyu Tolgoi Mine in Khanbogd Is Transforming Mongolia
item.description: Enormous reserves of gold and copper will bring prosperity, but at a human, cultural and environmental cost.
item.dc:creator: By KIT GILLET

item.title: Libya Attacks Came in Two Waves, Official Says
item.description: The mayhem that killed and wounded more than a dozen American officials was actually two attacks — the first spontaneous and the second organized, a top Libyan security official said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: The United States Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, on Thursday. An Interior Ministry official said the United States ambassador was killed in the initial attack.

item.title: WORLD: A Changing Landscape
item.description: While gold and copper mining have made Mongolia the world’s fastest-growing economy, they have also created some health and environmental problems in boom towns throughout the Gobi Desert.

item.title: Egypt, Hearing From Obama, Moves to Heal Rift From Protests
item.description: A blunt phone call from President Obama prompted Egyptian leaders to scramble Thursday to try to repair the country’s alliance with Washington.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, HELENE COOPER and MARK LANDLER
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man threw stones in Tahrir Square in Cairo on Thursday as protests continued. President Obama told President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt that he must speak out strongly against the protests.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Court Experts Broaden Blame in Cruise Ship Wreck Beyond Captain
item.description: Court-appointed experts said the captain was primarily to blame for the deadly cruise ship accident that killed 32 people in January, but also faulted the crew and the shipowner.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Film Backer Nakoula Basseley Nakoula Has Shadowy Past
item.description: Federal authorities identified Nakoula Basseley Nakoula as part of the network that produced an online video that has drawn violent protests across the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and SERGE F. KOVALESKI

item.title: Diplomats Pulled 2 Ways, Between Protection and Accessibility
item.description: An ambassador’s death most likely will only increase efforts to protect American diplomatic personnel from the chaos of the countries where they are posted.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Protesters on Thursday at the American Embassy in Sana, Yemen. There has long been debate among diplomats over whether building imposing diplomatic compounds is counterproductive.

item.title: Egypt, Not Libya, May Be Bigger Challenge for White House
item.description: The tepid response from the Egyptian government to violence at the American Embassy in Cairo gave American officials cause for worry.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and MARK LANDLER
item.media:credit: Moises Saman for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Thursday, for a third straight day, protesters scuffled with police in Cairo.

item.title: Obama Rebuffs Netanyahu on Nuclear ‘Red Line’ for Iran
item.description: President Obama on Tuesday rejected an appeal by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to spell out a specific “red line” that Iran could not cross in its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and HELENE COOPER

item.title: Haiti’s National Palace Being Demolished
item.description: The white French Renaissance palace, which ended up as little more than a symbol of the stalled recovery from the 2010 earthquake, will be ripped apart over the coming months and carted off.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The National Palace in Port-au-Prince, which has become a symbol of the stalled recovery, shown a week after an earthquake hit Haiti on Jan. 12, 2010.

item.title: Support for the Euro Is Seen in Dutch Election Results
item.description: Dutch voters appeared to give Prime Minister Mark Rutte a narrow victory, which will relieve European allies anxious about rising euro skepticism in the richer countries of the north.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Envoy Says Crisis Is Worsening
item.description: The diplomat tasked with ending Syria’s civil war said Thursday that the conflict was worsening, after traveling to the country for the first time since taking a job he has called “nearly impossible.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Google Blocks Inflammatory Video in Egypt and Libya
item.description: Google blocked an anti-Muslim video on YouTube, which it owns, in Egypt and in Libya, but did not take it down altogether.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: Glen Doherty, Killed in Libya, Led Life of Risks Overseas
item.description: For Glen Doherty, killed Tuesday in the attack on a diplomatic compound in Libya, being assigned to a high-stakes security detail was just one of many adventurous overseas missions.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JESS BIDGOOD
item.media:credit: Quigley Family Photo, via Associated Press

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Measures in Deadly Clashes
item.description: President Mwai Kibaki fired an assistant minister after he was charged in court with inciting clashes in the southeast that have killed 110 people in three weeks.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Acknowledges ‘Excesses’ in His Macho Televised Adventures
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin has admitted that some of his most famous news media adventures with wildlife have been staged, but noted they drew attention to conservation.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.N. Nuclear Watchdog Passes Resolution on Iran
item.description: The International Atomic Energy Agency adopted a measure that rebuked Iran for defying demands to curb its uranium enrichment and expressed concern about its nuclear advances.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Volcano Erupts Near Tourist Site in Guatemala
item.description: A long-simmering volcano’s powerful eruptions outside one of Guatemala’s most famous tourist attractions on Thursday prompted evacuation orders for more than 33,000 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Anger and Grief Across Karachi After Factory Fire
item.description: Several survivors said Thursday that as the fire spread, plant managers forced them to stay in order to save the company’s stock: piles of stonewashed jeans.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: The remains of a factory in Karachi after a fire killed 289 people.

item.title: Mexico Captures El Coss, Head of Gulf Cartel
item.description: Jorge Eduardo Costilla Sánchez, known as El Coss, was arrested Wednesday afternoon, the Mexican Navy said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: Marines flanked Jorge Eduardo Costilla Sánchez, the top leader of the Gulf Cartel, in Mexico City on Thursday.
